p: Podophyllotoxin is used in the development of the commercially available anti-cancer drugs etoposide and teniposide, which are used against neuroblastoma, testicular cancer, lung cancer, hepatoma and others [ 7, 8, 9], and are also used for the treatment of psoriasis and malaria [ 10, 11]. Currently, podophyllotoxin is commercially isolated from the Himalayan mayapple ( Podophyllum hexandrum Royle), an endangered species. Some junipers and other species have shown promise as alternative feedstock for podophyllotoxin [ 4, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19]. The juniper species in Eastern Europe have not been fully explored as sources for podophyllotoxin and for EOs with specific aromas that would be of interest for the industry.
